Award.AwardTitle: Three dimensional modeling of dynamic microstructure
Award.AbstractNarration:
Small amounts of melting in the silicate part of the Earth's deep interior exert a disproportionate influence on the physical and chemical properties of rocks. Melt is often distributed in tubes, disks, or pockets, whose dimensions are as small as the fraction of the width of a human hair. Relative abundance of these different shapes of melt units depend on both the dynamic environment of melting and chemical composition of the melts. The signature of melt geometry, an averaged description of melt distribution in these various units, is sampled by earthquake waves passing through these regions. Deciphering the signals of these earthquake waves, one can find out about the processes associated with melting in the deep Earth.

In this project, we continue to develop a new theoretical toolbox, `microgeodynamics', to address the issues of detection of partial melting in the Earth?s interior and dynamics of melt storage and segregation. We will study the influence of melt volume fraction, wetting behavior, and deformation on the physical properties such as elastic moduli and melt mobility using a SemiAnalytical Model (SAM) and a Boundary Elements Model (BEM). The output of these models, dynamic melt geometry, will be processed to explain observed anomalies in various physical properties in the Earth's deep interior.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The research in this project focused on characterizing the microstructure of multiphase rocks and understanding the implications for melt migration and storage in the Earth. This research led to 9 published articles, 5 articles under peer-review, over 20 contributed international conference presentations, and several published databases. The key scientific outcomes of this project are briefly discussed below.

 

Quantification of melting in the mantle: A crucial outcome of this work involved quantifying the extent of melting from seismic signature of a low velocity layer above the mantle transition zone, at a depth of 350 km. One of our results included the discovery of a vast (1.8 million square km) partially molten region beneath the western US, which was covered by the press in the US and abroad.

Model of microstructure: Using a new fast multipole boundary elements method, we created a new model tracking the development of textural anisotropy in partially molten rocks. Our results indicated that the velocity of seismic waves can be significantly altered by a mechanism called shear wave splitting, due the development of this anisotropy.

X-Ray microtomography: In a collaboartive research with another grant from NERC, UK, we studied the pore network geoemtry and permeability of natural sandstones and limestones. One outcome of this work showed that the permeability of carbonate cement bearing rocks decrease during the process of cementation. This result can have strong implications for carbon capture and sequestration.
